**Transcript**:
We get it, not everyone loves snakes. You may not want to encounter one
in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species
of viper worldwide. The name comes from the term viviparity,
which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
to the roofs of their mouths. This allows the fangs to be extra long, unfolding into imposing weapons
when the viper prepares to strike. So how about we pay them a surprise visit? First stop: 
the southeastern United States, where we can hear the viper
before we can see it. The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is
the largest of 36 species of rattlesnake. Rattlesnakes can shake their rattles
up to 90 times per second to warn off predators 
for hours if needed. The rattle consists of hollow, interlocked
segments made of keratin, the same substance that makes
our nails and hair. When the snake shakes its tail,
these segments hit each other, creating a shockingly loud noise. Now onto the mountains of western Iran,
where a spider crawls across a rock, making easy prey for a passing bird—
or not. The spider-tailed horned viper is
perfectly camouflaged, almost invisible, except for its unique bulbous tail-tip
with long drooping scales that look like a leggy spider. Spider-tailed vipers
are only about 50 centimeters long, so they can lure small birds 
within striking range without compromising their ability 
to squeeze into narrow rock crevices. In the rainforests of Latin America 
lives a viper that couldn’t be more different
from the spider-tailed viper— if you can find it. It’s one of the most elusive snakes
in the world: the bushmaster. The bushmaster is a pit viper. Between each eye and nostril,
it has a heat-sensing pit with a membrane covered 
in highly sensitive receptors that respond to temperature changes as small as one one-thousandth 
of a degree Celsius. These pits gather infrared information
that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see” 
the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, helping it decide whether or not to strike
and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers,

or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the

kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
We get it, not everyone loves snakes. You may not want to encounter one
in the wild. To each their own! That’s why we’re here, 
to take you on a world tour of some of nature’s most incredible snakes
from the safety of your home— and with your very own intrepid guide. All the snakes we’ll be visiting
belong to a group called the vipers. As of 2021, there are 368 species
of viper worldwide. The name comes from the term viviparity,
which means giving birth to live young. Unlike most snakes, which lay eggs, most vipers have eggs 
that hatch inside the mother, who then gives birth 
to up to dozens of tiny snakes. Not glad you’re safe at home yet? Vipers are also often highly venomous, with two hollow fangs that fold flat
to the roofs of their mouths. This allows the fangs to be extra long, unfolding into imposing weapons
when the viper prepares to strike. So how about we pay them a surprise visit? First stop: 
the southeastern United States, where we can hear the viper
before we can see it. The eastern diamondback rattlesnake is
the largest of 36 species of rattlesnake. Rattlesnakes can shake their rattles
up to 90 times per second to warn off predators 
for hours if needed. The rattle consists of hollow, interlocked
segments made of keratin, the same substance that makes
our nails and hair. When the snake shakes its tail,
these segments hit each other, creating a shockingly loud noise. Now onto the mountains of western Iran,
where a spider crawls across a rock, making easy prey for a passing bird—
or not. The spider-tailed horned viper is
perfectly camouflaged, almost invisible, except for its unique bulbous tail-tip
with long drooping scales that look like a leggy spider. Spider-tailed vipers
are only about 50 centimeters long, so they can lure small birds 
within striking range without compromising their ability 
to squeeze into narrow rock crevices. In the rainforests of Latin America 
lives a viper that couldn’t be more different
from the spider-tailed viper— if you can find it. It’s one of the most elusive snakes
in the world: the bushmaster. The bushmaster is a pit viper. Between each eye and nostril,
it has a heat-sensing pit with a membrane covered 
in highly sensitive receptors that respond to temperature changes as small as one one-thousandth 
of a degree Celsius. These pits gather infrared information
that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum. This allows the bushmaster to “see” 
the heat signature of approaching prey or predators, helping it decide whether or not to strike
and strike more accurately. This comes in handy for guarding a nest— unlike most other vipers, 
the bushmaster lays eggs in hollowed out tree buttresses 
or burrows made by other animals. It must be large enough
to defend its nest— in fact, the bushmaster is the
largest viper in the world, reaching lengths of over 11 feet,
with huge fangs and deadly venom. Meanwhile, in the forests 
of sub-Saharan Africa, there’s a shorter, chunkier viper that’s 
even more venomous than the bushmaster. The African Gaboon viper has 
the longest fangs of any snake— yes, all 3,879 snake species, 
not just vipers— and can deliver 1,000 milligrams
of venom in a single bite— enough to kill ten adult humans. Although deadly, Gaboon vipers 
have a reputation for being slow-moving 
and placid creatures. When they do strike, they hold onto their 
rodent prey while the venom takes effect, then quickly swallow it down. At this point, you may be worrying
about our guide— but never fear, rodents like our little desert 
kangaroo rat have their own skills to evade the serpent’s tooth. They stomp their feet at rattlesnakes,
kick sand towards them, and evade their strikes 
with acrobatic leaps and powerful kicks— helping them live to guide 
another snake tour.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What do you find inside the rattle of a rattlesnake?
Options: A. Sand grains, B. balls of keratin, C. beads of old skin, D. nothing, its hollow
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
He was born in the 1330s 
in the Chaghatayid Khanate formerly the Mongol Empire
in Central Asia. On the unforgiving steppe,
he rose from a lowly sheep thief to become one of history’s 
greatest conquerors, uniting nearly all of Central Asia, 
Afghanistan, and Iran under his rule. But was he a great state builder 
or a bloodthirsty tyrant? Order! Order! 
Who do we have on the stand today? Tamer...lane? That wasn’t his name, your Honor. The great Timur— meaning iron—
was nicknamed “Timur the lame” by enemies who mocked permanent 
injuries to his leg and arm. Injuries he sustained raiding
a rival tribe’s sheep herd— he was a thief and a scoundrel
from the start! Maybe— we actually don’t know for sure—
but even if that’s true, raiding rivals was just part 
of nomadic life at the time. Timur was not born into a ruling family, so he had to prove his worth 
through daring and horsemanship. He was hardly a commoner. Timur’s family was minor nobility. His uncle and brother-in-law were
high-ranking officials. And when they trusted Timur
on a diplomatic mission, he defected to a rival khan! Strategic maneuvering! He reconciled with his uncle 
and brother-in-law soon after. Only for long enough to consolidate
his own power. Then he went to battle against
his brother-in-law— supposedly his closest ally. He was assassinated,
and Timur seized power! They may have been friends, but he was a corrupt man 
who alienated a lot of people. Timur was right to oust him. Afterward, he managed to reunite 
most of the khanate’s territories and put an end to decades 
of bloody infighting. Okay, so where are we?
I can hardly keep up. 1370, your honor. And he’s khan now? Well, not quite. Timur was not a direct descendant 
of Genghis Khan, so he couldn’t claim the title. Instead, he appointed figurehead khans
and referred to himself as amir, or commander, 
and later as güregen, or son-in-law, after he married a woman who was 
descended from Genghis Khan. He claimed to be a divinely ordained
protector of the Mongol and Muslim worlds, yet he undermined both 
Mongol and Muslim power by relentlessly waging
war against his neighbors, weakening them so much that Christian
Europe romanticized him as an ally. His campaigns killed as many 
as 17 million people! Propaganda. Timur’s official biographies deliberately 
exaggerated the number of deaths to deter rebellions. Like the Mongols, Timur offered
cities the chance to surrender and only ordered massacres
if they revolted. He rebuilt irrigation canals
to support agriculture, and regularly distributed
food to the poor. Just in his hometown of Kesh, he paid for the meat of 20 sheep 
to be given to the poor every day. His campaigns were brutal, but by unifying Central Asia,
Afghanistan, and Iran, he was also able to reinvigorate
the Silk Road. Much of Eurasia benefited from the revival
of long-distance trade, and Central Asian cities,
such as Samarkand and Herat, became thriving commercial hubs
under his rule. And meanwhile, other cities 
like Baghdad, Aleppo, and Delhi were plundered and burned
and took decades to recover. This illiterate warlord destroyed
centuries’ worth of cultural heritage, leaving nothing but pyramids
of skulls in his wake. Timur may have been illiterate, but he was also an active patron
of culture and the arts. During his conquests, 
he spared artisans and scholars, sending them to work on public projects
like schools and mosques. Unlike many women in the world
at the time, his wives, daughters, and daughters-in-law were highly educated 
and politically active. Timur also personally met with—
and impressed— the famed Arab historian 
Ibn Khaldun in Damascus, and he so thoroughly mastered chess
that he is said to have enjoyed a more complex variant 
that was named for him. So what happened after that? Timur died from an illness in 1405,
when he was likely in his early 70s. The empire he founded lasted 
another hundred years, ushering in an architectural, artistic,
literary and scientific renaissance across Central Asia. In Samarkand, Timur’s grandson, 
Ulugh Beg, built the largest astronomical observatory
in the world at the time. Even after the fall of Timur's empire, his descendant Babur re-established
himself in India, founding the Mughal Empire, which would become home to nearly 
a quarter of the world’s population and which built such splendors
as the Red Fort and Taj Mahal. Timur's legacy is still celebrated
in monuments across Central Asia, where he is remembered as 
“Buyuk Babamiz” or “our great forefather.” And yet today in Europe, India,
and much of the Middle East, he's remembered as a butcher. That’s more reflection of the success
of his own propaganda than of the man himself. Hold on now, I think
I’ve almost got the king cornered! Emerging from relative obscurity,
Timur’s conquests formed a legacy lasting nearly 500 years 
that remains on trial even today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the name Timur mean?
Options: A. Conqueror, B. Heaven, C. Wolf, D. Iron
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What event occurred on September 1st, 1859, and was caused by a solar storm? Options: A. The Great Fire of London, B. The Carrington Event, C. A solar eclipse, D. The Colorado Gold Rush Correct Option: B
Question 2: What generates Earth's magnetic field? Options: A. Convection in the Sun's plasma, B. Charged molten metals circulating in the planet's outer core, C. Solar storms, D. Coronal mass ejections Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the typical speed of plasma ejected from the Sun's surface during a coronal mass ejection? Options: A. Thousands of kilometers per hour, B. Thousands of kilometers per second, C. Millions of kilometers per hour, D. Millions of kilometers per second Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the result of high-energy particles exciting atmospheric atoms during a solar storm? Options: A. A decrease in atmospheric pressure, B. A decrease in temperature, C. A magnificent light show (aurora), D. A decrease in atmospheric oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 5: What can happen to electrical equipment during a solar storm? Options: A. It becomes more efficient, B. It becomes less efficient, C. It short-circuits, D. It becomes obsolete Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the name of the event that occurred in 1921, where powerful solar storms caused telephones and telegraph equipment around the globe to combust? Options: A. The Carrington Event, B. The Solar Storm of 1921, C. The Great Fire of 1921, D. The Aurora of 1921 Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the cycle that the Sun's magnetic activity follows? Options: A. The 11-year solar cycle, B. The 22-year cycle, C. The 33-year cycle, D. The 44-year cycle Correct Option: A
Question 8: What can be done to mitigate the effects of a solar storm on power grids? Options: A. Shutting off power grids in advance, B. Installing capacitors to absorb energy, C. Installing special shielding on satellites, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the potential impact of a solar storm as strong as the Carrington Event on our interconnected, electrified planet? Options: A. It could cause minor disruptions, B. It could cause moderate disruptions, C. It could devastate our planet, D. It could have no impact Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the Sun's magnetic activity following an 11-year cycle? Options: A. It gives us a window into when solar storms are most likely to occur, B. It gives us a window into when solar storms are least likely to occur, C. It has no significance, D. It is unpredictable Correct Option: A
Question 11: What can happen to satellites during a solar storm? Options: A. They become more efficient, B. They become less efficient, C. They are damaged, D. They are obsolete Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the result of a solar storm causing a sudden influx of energy to electrical systems? Options: A. The energy is absorbed, B. The energy is dissipated, C. The energy causes a short-circuit, D. The energy has no effect Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the primary source of the Earth's magnetic field? Options: A. The Sun's magnetic field, B. Charged molten metals circulating in the planet's outer core, C. Solar storms, D. Coronal mass ejections Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the typical distance that a coronal mass ejection covers between the Sun and the Earth? Options: A. A few days, B. A few weeks, C. A few months, D. A few years Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the result of high-energy particles interacting with atmospheric atoms during a solar storm? Options: A. A decrease in atmospheric pressure, B. A decrease in temperature, C. A magnificent light show (aurora), D. A decrease in atmospheric oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 16: What can be done to mitigate the effects of a solar storm on satellites? Options: A. Installing special shielding, B. Shutting off satellites in advance, C. Installing capacitors to absorb energy, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 17: What is the significance of the Carrington Event? Options: A. It was the first recorded solar storm, B. It was the strongest solar storm in recorded history, C. It caused widespread damage to electrical systems, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 18: What is the primary effect of a solar storm on the Earth's atmosphere? Options: A. It causes a decrease in atmospheric pressure, B. It causes a decrease in temperature, C. It causes a magnificent light show (aurora), D. It causes a decrease in atmospheric oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 19: What is the typical speed of a coronal mass ejection? Options: A. Thousands of kilometers per hour, B. Thousands of kilometers per second, C. Millions of kilometers per hour, D. Millions of kilometers per second Correct Option: B
Question 20: What is the result of a solar storm interacting with the Earth's magnetic field? Options: A. It causes a decrease in magnetic field strength, B. It causes an increase in magnetic field strength, C. It causes a short-circuit, D. It has no effect Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Options: A. Conqueror, B. Heaven, C. Wolf, D. Iron

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
He was born in the 1330s 
in the Chaghatayid Khanate formerly the Mongol Empire
in Central Asia. On the unforgiving steppe,
he rose from a lowly sheep thief to become one of history’s 
greatest conquerors, uniting nearly all of Central Asia, 
Afghanistan, and Iran under his rule. But was he a great state builder 
or a bloodthirsty tyrant? Order! Order! 
Who do we have on the stand today? Tamer...lane? That wasn’t his name, your Honor. The great Timur— meaning iron—
was nicknamed “Timur the lame” by enemies who mocked permanent 
injuries to his leg and arm. Injuries he sustained raiding
a rival tribe’s sheep herd— he was a thief and a scoundrel
from the start! Maybe— we actually don’t know for sure—
but even if that’s true, raiding rivals was just part 
of nomadic life at the time. Timur was not born into a ruling family, so he had to prove his worth 
through daring and horsemanship. He was hardly a commoner. Timur’s family was minor nobility. His uncle and brother-in-law were
high-ranking officials. And when they trusted Timur
on a diplomatic mission, he defected to a rival khan! Strategic maneuvering! He reconciled with his uncle 
and brother-in-law soon after. Only for long enough to consolidate
his own power. Then he went to battle against

of bloody infighting. Okay, so where are we?
I can hardly keep up. 1370, your honor. And he’s khan now? Well, not quite. Timur was not a direct descendant 
of Genghis Khan, so he couldn’t claim the title. Instead, he appointed figurehead khans
and referred to himself as amir, or commander, 
and later as güregen, or son-in-law, after he married a woman who was 
descended from Genghis Khan. He claimed to be a divinely ordained
protector of the Mongol and Muslim worlds, yet he undermined both 
Mongol and Muslim power by relentlessly waging
war against his neighbors, weakening them so much that Christian
Europe romanticized him as an ally. His campaigns killed as many 
as 17 million people! Propaganda. Timur’s official biographies deliberately 
exaggerated the number of deaths to deter rebellions. Like the Mongols, Timur offered
cities the chance to surrender and only ordered massacres
if they revolted. He rebuilt irrigation canals
to support agriculture, and regularly distributed
food to the poor. Just in his hometown of Kesh, he paid for the meat of 20 sheep 
to be given to the poor every day. His campaigns were brutal, but by unifying Central Asia,
Afghanistan, and Iran, he was also able to reinvigorate
the Silk Road. Much of Eurasia benefited from the revival
of long-distance trade, and Central Asian cities,
such as Samarkand and Herat, became thriving commercial hubs
under his rule. And meanwhile, other cities 
like Baghdad, Aleppo, and Delhi were plundered and burned
and took decades to recover. This illiterate warlord destroyed
centuries’ worth of cultural heritage, leaving nothing but pyramids
of skulls in his wake. Timur may have been illiterate, but he was also an active patron
of culture and the arts. During his conquests, 
he spared artisans and scholars, sending them to work on public projects
like schools and mosques. Unlike many women in the world
at the time, his wives, daughters, and daughters-in-law were highly educated 
and politically active. Timur also personally met with—
and impressed— the famed Arab historian 
Ibn Khaldun in Damascus, and he so thoroughly mastered chess
that he is said to have enjoyed a more complex variant 
that was named for him. So what happened after that? Timur died from an illness in 1405,
when he was likely in his early 70s. The empire he founded lasted 
another hundred years, ushering in an architectural, artistic,
literary and scientific renaissance across Central Asia. In Samarkand, Timur’s grandson, 
Ulugh Beg, built the largest astronomical observatory
in the world at the time. Even after the fall of Timur's empire, his descendant Babur re-established
himself in India, founding the Mughal Empire, which would become home to nearly 
a quarter of the world’s population and which built such splendors
as the Red Fort and Taj Mahal. Timur's legacy is still celebrated
in monuments across Central Asia, where he is remembered as 
“Buyuk Babamiz” or “our great forefather.” And yet today in Europe, India,
and much of the Middle East, he's remembered as a butcher. That’s more reflection of the success
of his own propaganda than of the man himself. Hold on now, I think
I’ve almost got the king cornered! Emerging from relative obscurity,
Timur’s conquests formed a legacy lasting nearly 500 years 
that remains on trial even today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which title did Timur use?
Options: A. Amir, B. Sultan, C. Khan, D. Caliph
Correct Option: A

Question 8: What can be done to mitigate the effects of a solar storm on power grids? Options: A. Shutting off power grids in advance, B. Installing capacitors to absorb energy, C. Installing special shielding on satellites, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the potential impact of a solar storm as strong as the Carrington Event on our interconnected, electrified planet? Options: A. It could cause minor disruptions, B. It could cause moderate disruptions, C. It could devastate our planet, D. It could have no impact Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the Sun's magnetic activity following an 11-year cycle? Options: A. It gives us a window into when solar storms are most likely to occur, B. It gives us a window into when solar storms are least likely to occur, C. It has no significance, D. It is unpredictable Correct Option: A
Question 11: What can happen to satellites during a solar storm? Options: A. They become more efficient, B. They become less efficient, C. They are damaged, D. They are obsolete Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the result of a solar storm causing a sudden influx of energy to electrical systems? Options: A. The energy is absorbed, B. The energy is dissipated, C. The energy causes a short-circuit, D. The energy has no effect Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the primary source of the Earth's magnetic field? Options: A. The Sun's magnetic field, B. Charged molten metals circulating in the planet's outer core, C. Solar storms, D. Coronal mass ejections Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the typical distance that a coronal mass ejection covers between the Sun and the Earth? Options: A. A few days, B. A few weeks, C. A few months, D. A few years Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the result of high-energy particles interacting with atmospheric atoms during a solar storm? Options: A. A decrease in atmospheric pressure, B. A decrease in temperature, C. A magnificent light show (aurora), D. A decrease in atmospheric oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 16: What can be done to mitigate the effects of a solar storm on satellites? Options: A. Installing special shielding, B. Shutting off satellites in advance, C. Installing capacitors to absorb energy, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 17: What is the significance of the Carrington Event? Options: A. It was the first recorded solar storm, B. It was the strongest solar storm in recorded history, C. It caused widespread damage to electrical systems, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 18: What is the primary effect of a solar storm on the Earth's atmosphere? Options: A. It causes a decrease in atmospheric pressure, B. It causes a decrease in temperature, C. It causes a magnificent light show (aurora), D. It causes a decrease in atmospheric oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 19: What is the typical speed of a coronal mass ejection? Options: A. Thousands of kilometers per hour, B. Thousands of kilometers per second, C. Millions of kilometers per hour, D. Millions of kilometers per second Correct Option: B
Question 20: What is the result of a solar storm interacting with the Earth's magnetic field? Options: A. It causes a decrease in magnetic field strength, B. It causes an increase in magnetic field strength, C. It causes a short-circuit, D. It has no effect Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
He was born in the 1330s 
in the Chaghatayid Khanate formerly the Mongol Empire
in Central Asia. On the unforgiving steppe,
he rose from a lowly sheep thief to become one of history’s 
greatest conquerors, uniting nearly all of Central Asia, 
Afghanistan, and Iran under his rule. But was he a great state builder 
or a bloodthirsty tyrant? Order! Order! 
Who do we have on the stand today? Tamer...lane? That wasn’t his name, your Honor. The great Timur— meaning iron—
was nicknamed “Timur the lame” by enemies who mocked permanent 
injuries to his leg and arm. Injuries he sustained raiding
a rival tribe’s sheep herd— he was a thief and a scoundrel
from the start! Maybe— we actually don’t know for sure—
but even if that’s true, raiding rivals was just part 
of nomadic life at the time. Timur was not born into a ruling family, so he had to prove his worth 
through daring and horsemanship. He was hardly a commoner. Timur’s family was minor nobility. His uncle and brother-in-law were
high-ranking officials. And when they trusted Timur
on a diplomatic mission, he defected to a rival khan! Strategic maneuvering! He reconciled with his uncle 
and brother-in-law soon after. Only for long enough to consolidate
his own power. Then he went to battle against
his brother-in-law— supposedly his closest ally. He was assassinated,
and Timur seized power! They may have been friends, but he was a corrupt man 
who alienated a lot of people. Timur was right to oust him. Afterward, he managed to reunite 
most of the khanate’s territories and put an end to decades 
of bloody infighting. Okay, so where are we?
I can hardly keep up. 1370, your honor. And he’s khan now? Well, not quite. Timur was not a direct descendant 
of Genghis Khan, so he couldn’t claim the title. Instead, he appointed figurehead khans
and referred to himself as amir, or commander, 
and later as güregen, or son-in-law, after he married a woman who was 
descended from Genghis Khan. He claimed to be a divinely ordained
protector of the Mongol and Muslim worlds, yet he undermined both 
Mongol and Muslim power by relentlessly waging
war against his neighbors, weakening them so much that Christian
Europe romanticized him as an ally. His campaigns killed as many 
as 17 million people! Propaganda. Timur’s official biographies deliberately 
exaggerated the number of deaths to deter rebellions. Like the Mongols, Timur offered
cities the chance to surrender and only ordered massacres
if they revolted. He rebuilt irrigation canals
to support agriculture, and regularly distributed
food to the poor. Just in his hometown of Kesh, he paid for the meat of 20 sheep 
to be given to the poor every day. His campaigns were brutal, but by unifying Central Asia,
Afghanistan, and Iran, he was also able to reinvigorate
the Silk Road. Much of Eurasia benefited from the revival
of long-distance trade, and Central Asian cities,
such as Samarkand and Herat, became thriving commercial hubs
under his rule. And meanwhile, other cities 
like Baghdad, Aleppo, and Delhi were plundered and burned
and took decades to recover. This illiterate warlord destroyed
centuries’ worth of cultural heritage, leaving nothing but pyramids
of skulls in his wake. Timur may have been illiterate, but he was also an active patron
of culture and the arts. During his conquests, 
he spared artisans and scholars, sending them to work on public projects
like schools and mosques. Unlike many women in the world
at the time, his wives, daughters, and daughters-in-law were highly educated 
and politically active. Timur also personally met with—
and impressed— the famed Arab historian 
Ibn Khaldun in Damascus, and he so thoroughly mastered chess
that he is said to have enjoyed a more complex variant 
that was named for him. So what happened after that? Timur died from an illness in 1405,
when he was likely in his early 70s. The empire he founded lasted 
another hundred years, ushering in an architectural, artistic,
literary and scientific renaissance across Central Asia. In Samarkand, Timur’s grandson, 
Ulugh Beg, built the largest astronomical observatory
in the world at the time. Even after the fall of Timur's empire, his descendant Babur re-established
himself in India, founding the Mughal Empire, which would become home to nearly 
a quarter of the world’s population and which built such splendors
as the Red Fort and Taj Mahal. Timur's legacy is still celebrated
in monuments across Central Asia, where he is remembered as 
“Buyuk Babamiz” or “our great forefather.” And yet today in Europe, India,
and much of the Middle East, he's remembered as a butcher. That’s more reflection of the success
of his own propaganda than of the man himself. Hold on now, I think
I’ve almost got the king cornered! Emerging from relative obscurity,
Timur’s conquests formed a legacy lasting nearly 500 years 
that remains on trial even today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following is NOT listed in the video as something Timur did?
Options: A. Rebuild irrigation canals to support agriculture., B. Replace the covering of the Ka’bah in Mecca., C. Order food distributed to the poor., D. Revive long-distance Silk Road trade.
Correct Option: B

as the Red Fort and Taj Mahal. Timur's legacy is still celebrated
in monuments across Central Asia, where he is remembered as 
“Buyuk Babamiz” or “our great forefather.” And yet today in Europe, India,
and much of the Middle East, he's remembered as a butcher. That’s more reflection of the success
of his own propaganda than of the man himself. Hold on now, I think
I’ve almost got the king cornered! Emerging from relative obscurity,
Timur’s conquests formed a legacy lasting nearly 500 years 
that remains on trial even today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which game was Timur especially fond of?
Options: A. Chess, B. Checkers, C. Mahjong, D. Dice
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
He was born in the 1330s 
in the Chaghatayid Khanate formerly the Mongol Empire
in Central Asia. On the unforgiving steppe,
he rose from a lowly sheep thief to become one of history’s 
greatest conquerors, uniting nearly all of Central Asia, 
Afghanistan, and Iran under his rule. But was he a great state builder 
or a bloodthirsty tyrant? Order! Order! 
Who do we have on the stand today? Tamer...lane? That wasn’t his name, your Honor. The great Timur— meaning iron—
was nicknamed “Timur the lame” by enemies who mocked permanent 
injuries to his leg and arm. Injuries he sustained raiding
a rival tribe’s sheep herd— he was a thief and a scoundrel
from the start! Maybe— we actually don’t know for sure—
but even if that’s true, raiding rivals was just part 
of nomadic life at the time. Timur was not born into a ruling family, so he had to prove his worth 
through daring and horsemanship. He was hardly a commoner. Timur’s family was minor nobility. His uncle and brother-in-law were
high-ranking officials. And when they trusted Timur
on a diplomatic mission, he defected to a rival khan! Strategic maneuvering! He reconciled with his uncle 
and brother-in-law soon after. Only for long enough to consolidate
his own power. Then he went to battle against
his brother-in-law— supposedly his closest ally. He was assassinated,
and Timur seized power! They may have been friends, but he was a corrupt man 
who alienated a lot of people. Timur was right to oust him. Afterward, he managed to reunite 
most of the khanate’s territories and put an end to decades 
of bloody infighting. Okay, so where are we?
I can hardly keep up. 1370, your honor. And he’s khan now? Well, not quite. Timur was not a direct descendant 
of Genghis Khan, so he couldn’t claim the title. Instead, he appointed figurehead khans
and referred to himself as amir, or commander, 
and later as güregen, or son-in-law, after he married a woman who was 
descended from Genghis Khan. He claimed to be a divinely ordained
protector of the Mongol and Muslim worlds, yet he undermined both 
Mongol and Muslim power by relentlessly waging
war against his neighbors, weakening them so much that Christian
Europe romanticized him as an ally. His campaigns killed as many 
as 17 million people! Propaganda. Timur’s official biographies deliberately 
exaggerated the number of deaths to deter rebellions. Like the Mongols, Timur offered
cities the chance to surrender and only ordered massacres
if they revolted. He rebuilt irrigation canals
to support agriculture, and regularly distributed
food to the poor. Just in his hometown of Kesh, he paid for the meat of 20 sheep 
to be given to the poor every day. His campaigns were brutal, but by unifying Central Asia,
Afghanistan, and Iran, he was also able to reinvigorate
the Silk Road. Much of Eurasia benefited from the revival
of long-distance trade, and Central Asian cities,
such as Samarkand and Herat, became thriving commercial hubs
under his rule. And meanwhile, other cities 
like Baghdad, Aleppo, and Delhi were plundered and burned
and took decades to recover. This illiterate warlord destroyed
centuries’ worth of cultural heritage, leaving nothing but pyramids
of skulls in his wake. Timur may have been illiterate, but he was also an active patron
of culture and the arts. During his conquests, 
he spared artisans and scholars, sending them to work on public projects
like schools and mosques. Unlike many women in the world
at the time, his wives, daughters, and daughters-in-law were highly educated 
and politically active. Timur also personally met with—
and impressed— the famed Arab historian 
Ibn Khaldun in Damascus, and he so thoroughly mastered chess
that he is said to have enjoyed a more complex variant 
that was named for him. So what happened after that? Timur died from an illness in 1405,
when he was likely in his early 70s. The empire he founded lasted 
another hundred years, ushering in an architectural, artistic,
literary and scientific renaissance across Central Asia. In Samarkand, Timur’s grandson, 
Ulugh Beg, built the largest astronomical observatory
in the world at the time. Even after the fall of Timur's empire, his descendant Babur re-established
himself in India, founding the Mughal Empire, which would become home to nearly 
a quarter of the world’s population and which built such splendors
as the Red Fort and Taj Mahal. Timur's legacy is still celebrated
in monuments across Central Asia, where he is remembered as 
“Buyuk Babamiz” or “our great forefather.” And yet today in Europe, India,
and much of the Middle East, he's remembered as a butcher. That’s more reflection of the success
of his own propaganda than of the man himself. Hold on now, I think
I’ve almost got the king cornered! Emerging from relative obscurity,
Timur’s conquests formed a legacy lasting nearly 500 years 
that remains on trial even today.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which was founded by one of Timur’s descendants?
Options: A. The Ottoman Empire, B. The Mughal Empire, C. The Golden Horde, D. The Mamluk Sultanate
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On September 1st, 1859, miners following 
the Colorado gold rush woke up to another sunny day. Or so they thought. To their surprise,
they soon discovered it was actually 1 am; and the sky wasn’t lit by the Sun,
but rather by brilliant drapes of light. The blazing glow could be seen as far 
as the Caribbean, leading people in many regions to believe
that nearby cities had caught fire. But the true cause of what would come
to be known as the Carrington Event was a solar storm—
the largest in recorded history. Solar storms are one of many astrophysical
phenomena caused by magnetic fields. These fields are generated by movements 
of electrically charged particles like protons and electrons. For example, Earth’s magnetic field 
is generated by charged molten metals circulating in the planet's outer core. Similarly, the Sun’s magnetic field 
is generated by large convective movements in the plasma that composes the star. As this plasma slowly swirls, it creates areas of intense magnetic
activity called sunspots. The magnetic fields that form 
near these regions often become twisted and strained. And when they’re stretched too far,
they snap into simpler configurations, releasing energy that launches plasma
from the Sun’s surface. These explosions are known 
as coronal mass ejections. The plasma— mostly made of protons 
and electrons— accelerates rapidly, quickly reaching thousands
of kilometers per second. A typical coronal mass ejection covers
the distance between the Sun and the Earth in just a couple of days, flowing along the magnetic field 
that permeates the solar system. And those that cross the Earth’s path
are drawn to its magnetic field lines, falling into the atmosphere 
around the planet’s magnetic poles. This tidal wave of high-energy particles
excites atmospheric atoms such as oxygen and nitrogen, causing them to rapidly shed
photons at various energy levels. The result is a magnificent light show
we know as the auroras. And while this phenomenon is usually 
only visible near the Earth’s poles, strong solar storms can bring in 
enough high energy particles to light up large stretches of the sky. The magnetic fields in our solar system
are nothing compared to those found in deep space. Some neutron stars generate fields 
100 billion times stronger than those found in sunspots. And the magnetic fields 
around supermassive black holes expel jets of gas that extend 
for thousands of light years. However, on Earth, even weak solar storms
can be surprisingly dangerous. While the storms that reach us 
are generally harmless to humans, the high-energy particles 
falling into the atmosphere create secondary magnetic fields, which in turn generate rogue currents 
that short-circuit electrical equipment. During the Carrington Event, the only widespread electrical
technology was the telegraph. But since then, we've only become more
dependent on electrical systems. In 1921, another powerful solar
storm caused telephones and telegraph equipment 
around the globe to combust. In New York, the entire railway system 
was shut down and fires broke out in the central control building. Comparatively weak storms in 1989 and 2003 turned off regions 
of the Canadian power grid and damaged multiple satellites. If we were hit by a storm as strong
as the Carrington Event today, it could devastate our interconnected,
electrified planet. Fortunately, we're not defenseless. After centuries of observing sunspots, researchers have learned 
the Sun’s usual magnetic activity follows an 11-year cycle, giving us a window into when solar storms
are most likely to occur. And as our ability to forecast
space weather has improved, so have our mitigation measures. Power grids can be shut off 
in advance of a solar storm, while capacitors can be installed 
to absorb the sudden influx of energy. Many modern satellites and spacecraft 
are equipped with special shielding to absorb the impact of a solar storm. But even with these safeguards, it’s hard to say how our technology 
will fare during the next major event. It’s possible we’ll be left with only
the aurora overhead to light the path forward.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What generates magnetic fields?
Options: A. The appearance of Auroras, B. The presence of electrically charged particles at rest, C. The movement of electrically charged particles, D. The presence of a compass
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main problem that the cartographer of Center Realm faces on their first day in the job? Options: A. The lack of a map of the continent, B. The arrival of new dragons that need to be assigned to regions, C. The creation of new regions to accommodate the dragons, D. The destruction of existing regions by the dragons Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the condition for fire and ice dragons to coexist peacefully? Options: A. They can border each other, but not touch at the same point, B. They can touch at corners, C. They must be in different regions, D. They can be in the same region Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the key to coloring the map with two colors when there are points where lines meet? Options: A. The number of regions around each point must be odd, B. The number of regions around each point must be even, C. The color of the region must be determined by the type of dragon, D. The color of the region must be determined by the type of territory Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the consequence of adding a new line to the map that connects meeting points? Options: A. It creates a new region that touches two meeting points, B. It creates a new region that touches one meeting point, C. It creates a new region that does not touch any meeting points, D. It does not create a new region Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main challenge in creating a new region for the 17 elder dragons in the Western Sea? Options: A. The number of regions that can be created is limited, B. The number of dragons that can be accommodated is limited, C. The type of dragons that can be accommodated is limited, D. The size of the new region is limited Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the method used to identify problem areas in the map? Options: A. Focusing on one area and starting to color, B. Creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions, C. Drawing lines between points where multiple problematic regions touch, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the result of subdividing the giant territory into smaller ones? Options: A. Coloring the map becomes a logic puzzle, B. The map becomes easier to color, C. The number of regions increases, D. The number of dragons decreases Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the key to approaching the coloring of the map systematically? Options: A. Starting in one area and radiating out, B. Focusing on one type of dragon at a time, C. Creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions, D. Drawing lines between points where multiple problematic regions touch Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the consequence of not creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions? Options: A. The map becomes easier to color, B. The number of regions increases, C. The number of dragons decreases, D. The map becomes impossible to color Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of the cartographer? Options: A. To create a map that can be colored with two colors, B. To accommodate all the dragons in the continent, C. To save the continent from destruction, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a completely different topic, such as cartography and dragons, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to magnetic fields and electrically charged particles.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure of the question, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you want me to choose an index, I would say -1 or "None" as there isn't a matching generated MCQ.

Question: Areas of intense magnetic activity on the surface of the Sun are characterized by ____.
Options: A. The absence of sunspots, B. Stronger emission of light, C. A compass needle spinning all around, D. The presence of many sunspots
Correct Option: D

Question 9: What is the consequence of not creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions? Options: A. The map becomes easier to color, B. The number of regions increases, C. The number of dragons decreases, D. The map becomes impossible to color Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of the cartographer? Options: A. To create a map that can be colored with two colors, B. To accommodate all the dragons in the continent, C. To save the continent from destruction, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On September 1st, 1859, miners following 
the Colorado gold rush woke up to another sunny day. Or so they thought. To their surprise,
they soon discovered it was actually 1 am; and the sky wasn’t lit by the Sun,
but rather by brilliant drapes of light. The blazing glow could be seen as far 
as the Caribbean, leading people in many regions to believe
that nearby cities had caught fire. But the true cause of what would come
to be known as the Carrington Event was a solar storm—
the largest in recorded history. Solar storms are one of many astrophysical
phenomena caused by magnetic fields. These fields are generated by movements 
of electrically charged particles like protons and electrons. For example, Earth’s magnetic field 
is generated by charged molten metals circulating in the planet's outer core. Similarly, the Sun’s magnetic field 
is generated by large convective movements in the plasma that composes the star. As this plasma slowly swirls, it creates areas of intense magnetic
activity called sunspots. The magnetic fields that form 
near these regions often become twisted and strained. And when they’re stretched too far,
they snap into simpler configurations, releasing energy that launches plasma
from the Sun’s surface. These explosions are known 
as coronal mass ejections. The plasma— mostly made of protons 
and electrons— accelerates rapidly, quickly reaching thousands
of kilometers per second. A typical coronal mass ejection covers
the distance between the Sun and the Earth in just a couple of days, flowing along the magnetic field 
that permeates the solar system. And those that cross the Earth’s path
are drawn to its magnetic field lines, falling into the atmosphere 
around the planet’s magnetic poles. This tidal wave of high-energy particles
excites atmospheric atoms such as oxygen and nitrogen, causing them to rapidly shed
photons at various energy levels. The result is a magnificent light show
we know as the auroras. And while this phenomenon is usually 
only visible near the Earth’s poles, strong solar storms can bring in 
enough high energy particles to light up large stretches of the sky. The magnetic fields in our solar system
are nothing compared to those found in deep space. Some neutron stars generate fields 
100 billion times stronger than those found in sunspots. And the magnetic fields 
around supermassive black holes expel jets of gas that extend 
for thousands of light years. However, on Earth, even weak solar storms
can be surprisingly dangerous. While the storms that reach us 
are generally harmless to humans, the high-energy particles 
falling into the atmosphere create secondary magnetic fields, which in turn generate rogue currents 
that short-circuit electrical equipment. During the Carrington Event, the only widespread electrical
technology was the telegraph. But since then, we've only become more
dependent on electrical systems. In 1921, another powerful solar
storm caused telephones and telegraph equipment 
around the globe to combust. In New York, the entire railway system 
was shut down and fires broke out in the central control building. Comparatively weak storms in 1989 and 2003 turned off regions 
of the Canadian power grid and damaged multiple satellites. If we were hit by a storm as strong
as the Carrington Event today, it could devastate our interconnected,
electrified planet. Fortunately, we're not defenseless. After centuries of observing sunspots, researchers have learned 
the Sun’s usual magnetic activity follows an 11-year cycle, giving us a window into when solar storms
are most likely to occur. And as our ability to forecast
space weather has improved, so have our mitigation measures. Power grids can be shut off 
in advance of a solar storm, while capacitors can be installed 
to absorb the sudden influx of energy. Many modern satellites and spacecraft 
are equipped with special shielding to absorb the impact of a solar storm. But even with these safeguards, it’s hard to say how our technology 
will fare during the next major event. It’s possible we’ll be left with only
the aurora overhead to light the path forward.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long does it take for a typical coronal mass ejection to reach Earth?
Options: A. Less than 10 seconds, B. A few days, C. Months, D. Coronal mass ejections never reach Earth
Correct Option: B

The color of the region must be determined by the type of territory Correct Option: B

It creates a new region that touches one meeting point, C. It creates a new region that does not touch any meeting points, D. It does not create a new region Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main challenge in creating a new region for the 17 elder dragons in the Western Sea? Options: A. The number of regions that can be created is limited, B. The number of dragons that can be accommodated is limited, C. The type of dragons that can be accommodated is limited, D. The size of the new region is limited Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the method used to identify problem areas in the map? Options: A. Focusing on one area and starting to color, B. Creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions, C. Drawing lines between points where multiple problematic regions touch, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the result of subdividing the giant territory into smaller ones? Options: A. Coloring the map becomes a logic puzzle, B. The map becomes easier to color, C. The number of regions increases, D. The number of dragons decreases Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the key to approaching the coloring of the map systematically? Options: A. Starting in one area and radiating out, B. Focusing on one type of dragon at a time, C. Creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions, D. Drawing lines between points where multiple problematic regions touch Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the consequence of not creating a new region that touches multiple problematic regions? Options: A. The map becomes easier to color, B. The number of regions increases, C. The number of dragons decreases, D. The map becomes impossible to color Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s your first day in your new job 
as Center Realm’s official cartographer, and you've already got a big problem. Center Realm is home to three 
elder dragons: two ice, one fire, and they’ve lived in harmony 
on the east coast for centuries. But scouts have sighted three fire dragons
and five ice dragons flying across the Western Ocean. You’ll only have a few hours to assign 
them their designated regions before they’ll arrive. Elder dragons are extremely territorial. Each must have its own, 
officially acknowledged stomping ground. They’ll peacefully roost there unless
their region borders another dragon of the same type, in which case the matching dragons 
will go on a rampage. However, fire and ice dragons 
can border each other, and matching regions can touch at corners. You’ll soon have 11 dragons
and just 8 regions. Fortunately, you have enough 
political capital to create 3 new regions, each of which must be 
completely enclosed spaces. Add more or otherwise mess this up,
and you’ll lose your job and your head. Where do you draw lines 
and place the new dragons? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 It isn't difficult to create
three new regions. What is more challenging 
is to make sure the result will keep each dragon
away from its own kind. For instance, this can be 
neither ice nor fire, because it borders both. However, create a new region like this,
and suddenly there are viable options. Why did that work? Look at the point
where these four regions meet. If you go around it, it alternates
between fire and ice. Before the new line was added,
that wouldn’t have worked. Nor would 5 or 7 regions. 6 and 8, however, both do. The pattern is that points where lines
meet must be surrounded by an even number of regions. As long as that’s true, you can color 
the map in two colors, by alternating them around those points. In our initial arrangement,
there were six such meeting points. So what we want to do is connect
those to each other. Each line adds a single new region
that touches both meeting points. There are several ways to do this
to accommodate all 8 new dragons. You’ve done such a great job 
that your boss puts you in a ship and sends you out across the Western Sea
to investigate where these new dragons are coming from. There you’re met
with a civilization in disarray. Their 17 elder dragons are ravaging 
the countryside, wiping out the peasants, devastating all the people 
and their thatch-roofed cottages. And here there aren't just ice and fire
dragons, but lightning dragons too. Their people will only allow 
the creation of two new regions. Where do you create new regions
and place all the dragons? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Unfortunately, our meeting-point trick
won’t suffice now that there are three dragon types, so we need to find another
method to identify problem areas. A great way to do so is to experiment: focus on one area and start coloring
until we run out of possibilities. Take this section. These 3 regions all border each other,
so they need to be different colors. But they also all touch this giant
territory, which we now can’t color. To generalize the issue, when there are
4 regions that all border each other, it's impossible to color
them with three colors. The map has two other such areas. So what you need to do is break them up. And once again, the key is drawing lines
between points where multiple problematic regions touch. No matter how you do it, you’ll effectively subdivide 
the giant territory into smaller ones. Now coloring the map becomes
a logic puzzle. So long as you approach it systematically
by starting in one area and radiating out, you’ll reach an arrangement 
that you can fit all your dragons into, shifting the colors as needed. Just assign this region last, 
because it’ll have two options. You've saved not one, but two continents
from certain ruin. Now to see if you can find a giant eagle
and hitch a ride back home.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Elder dragons like their home region to be:
Options: A. Square, B. Rectangular, C. Circular, D. Any shape at all
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the ancient Chinese philosopher who proposed the idea that we might be dreaming of being a different creature? Options: A. Confucius, B. Zhuangzi, C. Lao Tzu, D. Mencius Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what characteristic of dreams makes it difficult to distinguish between reality and dreams? Options: A. Dreams are less vivid than reality, B. Dreams are disconnected from our waking lives, C. Dreams are less detailed than reality, D. Dreams are more predictable than reality Correct Option: B
Question 3: What 17th century French philosopher suggested that dreams are disconnected from our waking lives? Options: A. René Descartes, B. Thomas Hobbes, C. al-Ghazali, D. Zhuangzi Correct Option: A
Question 4: What philosopher suggested that we might be in a dream-state when we think we're awake? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one of the challenges in distinguishing between reality and dreams? Options: A. Dreams are less detailed than reality, B. Any test used to prove we're awake could take place in a dream, C. Dreams are more predictable than reality, D. We can't wake up in a dream Correct Option: B
Question 6: What philosopher suggested that we might wake from our current state into another state of even greater wakefulness? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the transcript, what characteristic of our waking experience makes it difficult to simulate in dreams? Options: A. Our memories are less detailed than our waking experiences, B. Our waking experiences are less vivid than our dreams, C. Our waking experiences contain an almost incomprehensibly vast amount of detail, D. Our waking experiences are less predictable than our dreams Correct Option: C
Question 8: Who pointed out that we should question our belief that we're awake? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is one of the challenges in proving that we're awake? Options: A. We can't wake up in a dream, B. Any test used to prove we're awake could take place in a dream, C. Dreams are less detailed than reality, D. We can't remember our dreams Correct Option: B
Question 10: Who pointed out that our memories capture just a fraction of our waking experience? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ is related to the topic of elder dragons and their home regions, while the generated MCQs are related to philosophers and dreams.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure of the question, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

So, my answer would be: None, but if you insist, Question 7 (Index: 7).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s your first day in your new job 
as Center Realm’s official cartographer, and you've already got a big problem. Center Realm is home to three 
elder dragons: two ice, one fire, and they’ve lived in harmony 
on the east coast for centuries. But scouts have sighted three fire dragons
and five ice dragons flying across the Western Ocean. You’ll only have a few hours to assign 
them their designated regions before they’ll arrive. Elder dragons are extremely territorial. Each must have its own, 
officially acknowledged stomping ground. They’ll peacefully roost there unless
their region borders another dragon of the same type, in which case the matching dragons 
will go on a rampage. However, fire and ice dragons 
can border each other, and matching regions can touch at corners. You’ll soon have 11 dragons
and just 8 regions. Fortunately, you have enough 
political capital to create 3 new regions, each of which must be 
completely enclosed spaces. Add more or otherwise mess this up,
and you’ll lose your job and your head. Where do you draw lines 
and place the new dragons? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 It isn't difficult to create
three new regions. What is more challenging 
is to make sure the result will keep each dragon
away from its own kind. For instance, this can be 
neither ice nor fire, because it borders both. However, create a new region like this,
and suddenly there are viable options. Why did that work? Look at the point
where these four regions meet. If you go around it, it alternates
between fire and ice. Before the new line was added,
that wouldn’t have worked. Nor would 5 or 7 regions. 6 and 8, however, both do. The pattern is that points where lines
meet must be surrounded by an even number of regions. As long as that’s true, you can color 
the map in two colors, by alternating them around those points. In our initial arrangement,
there were six such meeting points. So what we want to do is connect
those to each other. Each line adds a single new region
that touches both meeting points. There are several ways to do this
to accommodate all 8 new dragons. You’ve done such a great job 
that your boss puts you in a ship and sends you out across the Western Sea
to investigate where these new dragons are coming from. There you’re met
with a civilization in disarray. Their 17 elder dragons are ravaging 
the countryside, wiping out the peasants, devastating all the people 
and their thatch-roofed cottages. And here there aren't just ice and fire
dragons, but lightning dragons too. Their people will only allow 
the creation of two new regions. Where do you create new regions
and place all the dragons? Pause here to figure it out for yourself.
Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 Unfortunately, our meeting-point trick
won’t suffice now that there are three dragon types, so we need to find another
method to identify problem areas. A great way to do so is to experiment: focus on one area and start coloring
until we run out of possibilities. Take this section. These 3 regions all border each other,
so they need to be different colors. But they also all touch this giant
territory, which we now can’t color. To generalize the issue, when there are
4 regions that all border each other, it's impossible to color
them with three colors. The map has two other such areas. So what you need to do is break them up. And once again, the key is drawing lines
between points where multiple problematic regions touch. No matter how you do it, you’ll effectively subdivide 
the giant territory into smaller ones. Now coloring the map becomes
a logic puzzle. So long as you approach it systematically
by starting in one area and radiating out, you’ll reach an arrangement 
that you can fit all your dragons into, shifting the colors as needed. Just assign this region last, 
because it’ll have two options. You've saved not one, but two continents
from certain ruin. Now to see if you can find a giant eagle
and hitch a ride back home.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ice dragons ’ neighbors must be:
Options: A. Ice dragons, B. Anything but ice dragons, C. Fire dragons, D. Lightning dragons
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the ancient Chinese philosopher who proposed the idea that we might be dreaming of being a different creature? Options: A. Confucius, B. Zhuangzi, C. Lao Tzu, D. Mencius Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what characteristic of dreams makes it difficult to distinguish between reality and dreams? Options: A. Dreams are less vivid than reality, B. Dreams are disconnected from our waking lives, C. Dreams are less detailed than reality, D. Dreams are more predictable than reality Correct Option: B
Question 3: What 17th century French philosopher suggested that dreams are disconnected from our waking lives? Options: A. René Descartes, B. Thomas Hobbes, C. al-Ghazali, D. Zhuangzi Correct Option: A
Question 4: What philosopher suggested that we might be in a dream-state when we think we're awake? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is one of the challenges in distinguishing between reality and dreams? Options: A. Dreams are less detailed than reality, B. Any test used to prove we're awake could take place in a dream, C. Dreams are more predictable than reality, D. We can't wake up in a dream Correct Option: B
Question 6: What philosopher suggested that we might wake from our current state into another state of even greater wakefulness? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the transcript, what characteristic of our waking experience makes it difficult to simulate in dreams? Options: A. Our memories are less detailed than our waking experiences, B. Our waking experiences are less vivid than our dreams, C. Our waking experiences contain an almost incomprehensibly vast amount of detail, D. Our waking experiences are less predictable than our dreams Correct Option: C
Question 8: Who pointed out that we should question our belief that we're awake? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is one of the challenges in proving that we're awake? Options: A. We can't wake up in a dream, B. Any test used to prove we're awake could take place in a dream, C. Dreams are less detailed than reality, D. We can't remember our dreams Correct Option: B
Question 10: Who pointed out that our memories capture just a fraction of our waking experience? Options: A. Zhuangzi, B. al-Ghazali, C. Thomas Hobbes, D. René Descartes Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, discussing philosophers and the nature of reality and dreams, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to the transcript about dragons and their territories.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure, I would say that none of them are similar. But if you insist on an answer, I would say Question 5 is the most similar in terms of format, but it's still not related to the content of the ground truth MCQ.

The generated MCQs appear to be related to a different topic, discussing philosophers and the nature of reality and dreams, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to the transcript, which discusses cartography and the placement of dragons in a fictional realm.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and structure of the question, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you want me to choose an index, I would say -1 or "None" as an answer, but since you want a numerical index, I will choose the first index, but please note that the first generated MCQ doesn't match the ground truth MCQ.
